Humans are the dominant life form on Earth

the Anthopocene age has been named after them

23.54.text:
have created an advanced civilisation that
spans the globe and travels in space. weve

been told humans became this wondrous people
from a loose bands of hunter gathers, scattered

29.72.text:
around the globe some 10000 yrs ago - before

people with no technology, unable to navigate

existence - with basic tools - they build

61.91.text:
kind..anywhere. Furthermore the current epoch

72.24.text:
rise to advanced civilisation and global influence

the case. - human history on earth is being

that change our knowledge and understanding

98.06.text:
on this planet. Its a story that some have

Tool use and meat eating 3.4 MA
these bones were found in Ethiopia by Shannon

135.46.text:
McPherron of the Max Planck Institute for
Evolutionary Anthropology -

176.28.text:
the Marks on these fossilised animal bones
indicate that early-human butchers were using

181.30.text:
stone tools as early as 3.4 million years
ago. The finds suggest that the evolution

192.20.text:
of tool use and meat-eating among our human
ancestors is more complex than existing theories

198.47.text:
admit. They also add to a growing body of
evidence that A. Afarensis may have been

206.34.text:
more human-like and less primitive than some
have assumed. mcpherron and his colleagues

209.58.text:
claim - the find is evidence that The first
known human tool wielder and meat lover was

210.45.text:
Australopithecus Afarensis, the only known
hominid species present in the region at the

211.15.text:
time. "Our ancestors were carving meat some
800,000 years earlier than previously thought.

211.85.text:
this discovery pushes back in time, two of
the fundamental behaviours that played such

219.15.text:
an important role in human evolution – meat
consumption and tool use,. the idea that the

228.65.text:
origins of stone tool use, meat consumption
and the origins of our genus Homo all occurred

234.75.text:
together, around 2.5 million years ago." is
no longer accurate - Instead, hominids experimented

245.28.text:
with stone tools to help them eat meat and
marrow much earlier. 1 million years earlier

252.62.text:
tool making - 2.9 MA
Up until now, the earliest clear evidence

263.15.text:
of making stone tools came from a 2.6-million-year-old
site in Ethiopia. An early human ancestor

270.45.text:
called Homo habilis likely made them.  Similar
“Oldowan style” tools, known for choppers

276.86.text:
with one refined edge, have been discovered
at several other sites in East and Southern

283.62.text:
Africa. But a new collection of stone tools
discovered in Kenya belong to a second, more

294.50.text:
advanced generation of toolmaking. Known as
Acheulian tools after a prominent archaeological

302.47.text:
site in France, they are larger, heavier and
have sharp cutting edges that are chipped

308.94.text:
from opposite sides into the familiar teardrop
shape. "The Acheulian tools represent a great

315.86.text:
technological leap," says Dennis Kent, a geologist
from Rutgers University in New Jersey . The

322.62.text:
Discovery of their earlier manufacture suggests
early humans were wielding sophisticated stone

339.26.text:
tools at least 300,000 years earlier than
thought - 1.9 MA - evolutionary evidence in

352.61.text:
human fossils shows that tool use and tool
making coupled with meat eating increased

357.84.text:
the size of the human brain and facilitated
the appearance of specialized gripping muscles

363.74.text:
for our thumbs and larger brains . The brains
of early hominids were about the same size

370.18.text:
as that of a chimpanzee. however During the
next million years or more a process of encephalization

377.59.text:
began, by the time of the arrival of Homo
Erectus in the fossil record, cranial capacity

384.03.text:
had doubled to 850cc - Randall Susman, University
of Chicago posits that - the modern anatomy

388.33.text:
of the human thumb is an evolutionary response
to the requirements associated with making

393.98.text:
and handling tools — He compared bones and
muscles of human and chimpanzee thumbs, finding

401.16.text:
that humans have 3 muscles which are lacking
in chimpanzees. Humans also have thicker metacarpals

405.11.text:
with broader heads, allowing more precise
grasping than the chimpanzee hand can perform.

416.68.text:
Until recently the oldest, unchallenged evidence
of human hunting came from a 400,000-year-old

423.56.text:
site in Germany - the evidence came from marks
left by spears on horse bones - horses were

431.83.text:
clearly being speared and their flesh eaten.
but new Evidence from ancient butchery site

438.72.text:
in Tanzania - -shows early man used complex
hunting techniques to ambush and kill antelopes,

445.31.text:
gazelles, wildebeest and other large animals
at least two million years ago.- The discovery

454.57.text:
– by anthropologist Professor Henry Bunn
of Wisconsin University – pushes back the

459.66.text:
definitive date for the beginning of systematic
human hunting - by hundreds of thousands of

464.99.text:
years.
Two million years ago, our human ancestors

469.04.text:
were small-brained apemen previously many
scientists assumed the meat they butchered

474.90.text:
and ate had been gathered from animals that
had died from natural causes - or had been

479.63.text:
left behind by lions, leopards and other carnivores
- "We know that humans ate meat two million

487.21.text:
years ago," said Bunn, - What was not clear
was the source of that meat. However, we have

498.14.text:
compared the type of prey killed by lions
and leopards today with the type of prey selected

503.34.text:
by humans in those days. This has shown that
men and women could not have been taking kill

509.34.text:
from other animals - or eating those that
had died of natural causes. They were selecting

517.20.text:
and killing what they wanted."
Once our species got a taste for meat, it

523.15.text:
was provided with a dense, protein-rich source
of energy. We no longer needed to invest internal

529.90.text:
resources on huge digestive tracts - previously
required to process vegetation and fruit.

537.02.text:
This new, energy-rich resource was then diverted
inside our bodies and used to fuel our growing

546.70.text:
brains. over the next two million years our
crania grew, producing species of humans with

554.10.text:
increasingly large brains
Cooking & Fire 1.5 MA

570.56.text:
The ability to use fire is regarded as a key
step in human development because it gave

576.33.text:
us access to cooked foods and new technologies.
Evidence to determine exactly when humans

582.87.text:
acquired fire has been difficult to verify
- claims that the skill existed very early

588.85.text:
in human development have been challenged,
by sceptics arguing the fire remains from

593.56.text:
open sites, could have been the result of
natural blazes ignited by lightning. - In

600.42.text:
2012 Scientists announced the finding of new
evidence that our ancestors were using fire

606.25.text:
as early as a million years ago. It takes
the form of ash and bone fragments recovered

612.23.text:
from Wonderwerk Cave in South Africa. scientists
say the sediments in this cave show frequent,

625.23.text:
controlled fires were lit on the site. their
research describes burnt remains of grasses,

631.23.text:
brushes, leaves and even bones some 30m back
from the entrance. The depth of the sediments

637.43.text:
suggests fires were lit on the same spot over
and over again. This makes it far less likely

643.94.text:
that what they are viewing is material from
wildfires that was simply blown into the cave

649.12.text:
by wind. If correct, the Wonderwerk discovery
would push the earliest indisputable controlled

656.58.text:
use of fire back - by about 300,000 years
- earlier evidence from .East African sites,

664.90.text:
such as Chesowanja near Lake Baringo, show
possible evidence that fire was utilised by

671.00.text:
early humans. archaeologists found red clay
sherds dated to be 1.42 Mya.[4] Reheating

681.00.text:
on these sherds show that the clay must have
been heated to 400 °C (752 °F) to harden

685.64.text:
- this evidence of sustained heating makes
it likely humans were using fire at least

697.46.text:
It is already accepted that the addition of
meat in our ancestors' diet caused their brain

702.67.text:
size to increase and intelligence to grow.
the more concentrated form of energy - not

709.17.text:
only meant bigger brains for our ancestors,
but also reduced foraging time needed to maintain

715.54.text:
energy levels. As a consequence, more time
was available for social structure to develop.

722.72.text:
- Harvard Professor Richard Wrangham claims
it is not just a change in our diet, but the

727.66.text:
way in which we prepared meat that has caused
the radical evolution of our species." cooking

735.22.text:
is arguably the biggest increase in the quality
of the diet in the whole of the history of

739.99.text:
life," "Our ancestors most probably dropped
food in fire accidentally. They would have

746.30.text:
found it was delicious and that set us off
on a whole new direction." The eating of meat

751.63.text:
ties in with an evolutionary shift resulting
in a more human-looking ancestor with sharper

757.03.text:
teeth and a 30% bigger brain, called Homo
Habilis. - The most momentous shift however,

764.62.text:
happened 1.8 million years ago when Homo Erectus
- our first "truly human" ancestor arrived

772.00.text:
on the scene. - Homo Erectus had an even bigger
brain, smaller jaws and teeth.. Shorter arms

780.36.text:
and longer legs appeared, gone was the large
vegetable-processing gut, meaning that Erectus

788.00.text:
could not only walk upright, but could also
run. He was cleverer and faster, and - according

796.73.text:
to Professor Wrangham - he had learned how
to cook."Cooking made our guts smaller,""guts

are costly in terms of energy. Individuals
that were born with small guts were able to

save energy, have more babies and survive
better." he says. "Once we cooked our food,

here we are then 1 MA - humans are making

animals, cooking food - their brain size has

people are known as Homo Erectus they are

spreading through Africa, Asia, and Europe
